intro: Lemna polyrhiza var. concolor, commonly known as the narrow-leaf watermeal, is a small, floating aquatic plant belonging to the family Araceae. It is characterized by its tiny, oval-shaped leaves that are typically less than 1 cm in length, often with a smooth or slightly serrated edge. The plant produces tiny, inconspicuous flowers that are usually submerged, followed by small, greenish-brown fruits. It thrives in freshwater environments such as ponds, lakes, and slow-moving streams. Its rapid growth rate and ability to form dense mats make it an important component of aquatic ecosystems.
